snippet: Cone-shaped cells on most petals act like a surface of Velcro that pollinating bees can cling to, especially when the wind blows strongly, a study finds.
abstract: Study in journal Functional Ecology finds that cone-shaped cells on the petals of flowering plants act like a surface of Velcro that pollinating bees can cling to.
lead_paragraph: Cone-shaped cells on most petals act like a surface of Velcro that pollinating bees can cling to, especially when the wind blows strongly, a study finds.

headline.print_headline: Flowers’ Cells Lay Out A Sticky Carpet for Bees
headline.seo: Flowers’ Petals Are a Sticky Carpet for Bees
headline.main: Flowers’ Cells Lay Out a Sticky Carpet for Bees
